content: The "Suicide Prevention for American Veterans Act" extends eligibility for domiciliary care for certain veterans who served in a theater of combat operations from 5 years to 15 years. It also includes a provision for reviewing the characterization or terms of discharge from the armed forces of individuals with mental health disorders alleged to affect their discharge terms. The Secretaries of the military departments must establish a process for covered individuals to challenge their discharge or separation from the Armed Forces. Covered individuals include those discharged for personality disorder or under punitive conditions alleging mental health issues related to their service. The Secretary of a military department must use boards for the correction of military records to carry out the process required for individuals challenging their discharge. When deciding on modifying discharge terms, consideration must be given to any mental health injury incurred during service and its impact on the discharge circumstances. Improvement of mental health care for veterans and military personnel by the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense. The Secretary concerned must evaluate mental health care and suicide prevention programs annually, using common metrics, identifying effective programs, and proposing best practices for individuals with mental health disorders or at risk of suicide. The evaluation of mental health care and suicide prevention programs must be conducted annually by an independent third party. Providers of health care must be trained to recognize and treat individuals at risk of suicide and symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder. Best practices for identifying at-risk individuals and providing quality mental health care should be disseminated. The term "Secretary concerned" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for matters concerning the Department of Veterans Affairs, and the Secretary of Defense for matters concerning the Department of Defense. Collaboration between Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense on health care matters. The Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs are collaborating to implement interoperable electronic health records with a timeline of 180 days for creating a health data source and allowing patients to download their medical records. The Blue Button Initiative aims to achieve full interoperability of personal health care information between the Departments within one year. Real-time data exchange and graphical user interface upgrades are also targeted within the same timeframe. Additionally, members of the Armed Forces and their dependents can opt for electronic health records. The Blue Button Initiative aims for interoperability of health care information between Departments within a year. Members of the Armed Forces and their dependents can opt for electronic health records. The Secretaries of Veterans Affairs and Defense will establish a uniform prescription formulary. The Secretaries of Veterans Affairs and Defense will establish a uniform prescription formulary for medication. PILOT PROGRAM FOR REPAYMENT OF EDUCATIONAL LOANS FOR PSYCHIATRISTS IN VETERANS HEALTH ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to repay educational loans for individuals pursuing psychiatric medicine degrees. Eligible individuals must have obtained loans for education from various sources and can include those pursuing undergraduate, doctor of medicine, or doctor of osteopathy degrees. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will implement a pilot program to repay educational loans for individuals pursuing psychiatric medicine degrees. Eligible individuals must be licensed or eligible for licensure in psychiatric medicine in the Veterans Health Administration or enrolled in a residency program leading to a specialty qualification in psychiatric medicine approved by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education. They must also demonstrate a commitment to a long-term career as a psychiatrist in the Veterans Health Administration. The Secretary will select at least 10 individuals each year for the pilot program. Participants must agree to serve in psychiatric medicine for the Veterans Health Administration. Loan repayments cover principal, interest, and related expenses. The pilot program offers loan repayment for educational expenses, with a limit of $60,000 per year of obligated service. Participants who fail to complete their service will be liable to repay the amount paid on their behalf. The pilot program offers loan repayment for educational expenses, with a limit of $60,000 per year of obligated service. Participants who fail to complete their service will be liable to repay the amount paid on their behalf. Any owed damages must be repaid to the United States within one year of the breach. A report on the pilot program must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 90 days of the program's termination. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for the pilot program, including standards for qualified loans and authorized payees, and terms for loan repayments. The report to Congress will cover the program's impact on the psychiatric workforce shortage, long-term stability, and strategies to improve veterans' physical and mental resiliency. The pilot program for loan repayments will expire three years after its commencement by the Secretary. SEC. 7. COMPTROLLER GENERAL STUDY ON PAY DISPARITIES OF PSYCHIATRISTS OF VETERANS HEALTH ADMINISTRATION. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on pay disparities among psychiatrists in the Veterans Health Administration, including an examination of contributing factors and recommendations for improving pay equity. A report will be submitted to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs within one year of completing the study. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs with the results of a study on pay disparities among psychiatrists in the Veterans Health Administration.
